Yes, I believe that graphic novels have gained increasing recognition as a legitimate form of literature in recent years. A number of factors have contributed to this change in perception. 

First, the rise of the graphic novel as a medium has led to an increasing number of high-quality works being created, with more and more talented writers and artists choosing to work in the genre. This has helped to break down some of the preconceptions about graphic novels being primarily for children or not being "serious" literature. 

Second, many of these high-quality graphic novels have been recognized and celebrated by the literary community, receiving awards and critical acclaim. This has helped to broaden the readership of graphic novels and draw more attention to their potential as a legitimate literary medium. 

Third, with the advent of digital publishing and online platforms, graphic novels have become more accessible than ever before, allowing readers from all over the world to discover and experience them. This has helped to make the genre more visible and widespread, further contributing to its legitimacy as a form of literature.

Overall, I believe that the growing recognition and acceptance of graphic novels as a legitimate form of literature are a reflection of the increasing diversity and richness of the literary landscape, as well as a testament to the power of visual storytelling to engage and enlighten readers of all ages and backgrounds.
